news-item.title: Kazakh ombudsman concerned over tension at steel company
news-item.source: BBC Monitoring Central Asia UnitSupplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring
news-item.text: Excerpt from report by state-owned Kazakh news agency Kazinform Astana, 26 March: The Office of the Human Rights Commissioner in Kazakhstan is concerned about the continuous social tension at the ArcelorMittal Temirtau joint-stock company [steel, ore and coal mining company in central Karaganda Region]. The office has voiced its position in an address to the management of the enterprise, the press service of the ombudsman has reported. "In the address, it draws attention to reports, which are being systematically circulated in the media, about the unsettled labour relations at the enterprise till this moment and discussions about staff reduction," the report circulated says. The office of the ombudsman mentions that a special working group visited the ArcelorMittal Temirtau joint-stock company in 2013 and revealed violations of the labour rights of the workers. [Passage omitted: details of the revealed violations] It notes that "many noted problems have not been solved till this moment." Given this, the office of the ombudsman points to the importance of harmonizing balance between the economic aspects of the development of the enterprise and the observance of the labour rights of the citizens. "Taking into consideration the current situation, the national human rights office drew the attention of the management of ArcelorMittal Temirtau joint-stock company to the need to take further measures to prevent social tension among the staff, taking into account the constitutional rights and interests of the workers," the report notes. Source: Kazinform, Astana, in Russian 0542 gmt 26 Mar 14
